ABSTRACT
Maintaining posture and comfort is a crucial aspect of patient care, particularly for
individuals who are bedridden or paralyzed. Prolonged immobility or improper posture
often leads to discomfort, musculoskeletal strain, and pressure-induced complications such
as bedsores. Conventional monitoring methods depend largely on caregiver observation,
which may result in delays and inconsistent tracking. To address this challenge, the
proposed project introduces a smart bedsheet system designed to continuously monitor and
improve patient posture. The system integrates Force Sensitive Resistor (FSR) sensors to
measure pressure distribution at 16 points in real time. The data is processed using an
Arduino Uno board with a multiplexer, enabling accurate assessment of sitting or lying time

and posture. Real-time feedback is provided through multiple interfaces: an OLED display
with buzzer alerts patients to prolonged immobility, while a red LED with buzzer signals
improper posture, thereby alerting caregivers. A green LED indicator confirms balanced
posture, and a reset switch allows for easy identification and restart of monitoring when
required. This design offers a non-invasive, low-cost, and portable solution for patient
posture management. By providing continuous monitoring and timely alerts, the system
helps prevent pressure ulcers, enhances patient comfort, and reduces caregiver burden.
Beyond hospitals, it has potential applications in rehabilitation centers and home healthcare,
making it a versatile tool for proactive patient management. In conclusion, the smart
bed

sheet system bridges the gap between patient comfort and clinical intervention,
contributing to safer and more effective healthcare for vulnerable individuals.

CHAPTER 1 INTRODUCTION
1.1 Background and Motivation
Long-term immobility and poor posture are critical challenges in patient care, particularly
among bedridden or paralyzed individuals. Prolonged pressure on specific body regions can
lead to pressure ulcers (bedsores), musculoskeletal strain, and severe discomfort. According
to the World Health Organization, pressure ulcers affect millions of patients worldwide,
with an estimated prevalence of 8–25% among hospitalized individuals. These ulcers not
only prolong hospital stays but also increase the risk of infections, pain, and mortality.
Traditional monitoring methods rely on manual observation by caregivers, which can be
inconsistent and delayed. To overcome these limitations, smart healthcare technologies
using pressure sensors and micro

controllers have emerged for continuous and accurate
monitoring.
This project introduces a Smart Bedsheet System that uses Force Sensitive Resistor (FSR)
sensors and Arduino Uno to monitor pressure distribution and detect patient posture in real
time. The system provides alerts through LEDs, a buzzer, and an OLED display to warn
about prolonged immobility or improper posture.
The motivation behind this project is to develop a low-cost, non-invasive, and portable
solution that enhances patient comfort, prevents pressure ulcers, and reduces caregiver
workload. It has wide applications in hospitals, rehabilitation centers, and home healthcare.
1.2 Problem Statement
Patients who are bedridden or paralyzed are at high risk of developing pressure ulcers and
musculoskeletal discomfort due to prol

onged immobility and improper posture. Traditional
posture monitoring methods rely mainly on manual observation by caregivers, which is
time-consuming, inconsistent, and prone to human error. Existing technologies for pressure
and posture monitoring are often expensive, complex, or non-portable, making them
unsuitable for widespread use in hospitals and home healthcare settings. Therefore, there is
a need for a reliable, real-time, and low-cost system capable of continuously monitoring a
patient’s posture and pressure distribution. Such a system should provide immediate alerts
to prevent complications, improve comfort, and assist caregivers in timely intervention. The
proposed Smart Bedsheet System addresses this gap by integrating Force Sensitive Resistor
(FSR) sensors, Arduino Uno, and a

lert mechanisms to enable efficient and continuous
posture monitoring.

capable of continuously monitoring patient posture and pressure distribution to prevent
discomfort and pressure ulcers. The system aims to provide real-time alerts through an

3.1 Requirements
3.1.1 Functional Requirements
The PressuCare Smart Bedsheet System is designed to monitor patient posture and
immobility in real time. The following functional requirements describe the key operations
that the system must perform to achieve its objectives.
1. Pressure Detection
• The system shall detect pressure at 16 body contact points using Force Sensitive
Resistor (FSR) sensors embedded in the bedsheet.
• Each FSR sensor shall measure the amount of pressure applied and convert it into a
corresponding electrical signal.
• The system shall capture and update pressure data continuously in real time.
2. Data Acquisition and Processing
• The Arduino Uno microcontroller shall collect data sequentially from all FSR
sensors through a CD74

HC4067 multiplexer.
• The system shall process sensor readings to identify posture patterns and immobility
durations.
• The microcontroller shall compare live readings with pre-calibrated threshold values
to determine:
o Balanced posture
o Improper posture
o Extended immobility
3. Posture Classification and Feedback
• If pressure is evenly distributed (balanced posture), the system shall activate a green
LED.
• When uneven or improper posture is detected, the system shall activate a red LED
and trigger a buzzer alarm.
• If prolonged immobility is detected (beyond a preset duration), the system shall
display a warning on the OLED screen and sound a buzzer to alert caregivers.

3.1.2 Performance Requirements
The PressuCare Smart Bedsheet System must deliver reliable, real-time, and accurate
monitoring of patient posture and immobility. The following performance criteria define the
expected operational capabilities and performance standards of the system.
1. Response Time
• The system shall process sensor data and update posture status within 1–2 seconds
of any pressure change.
• Alerts via LEDs, buzzer, and OLED display shall be triggered immediately (<2
seconds) after detecting improper posture or prolonged immobility.
• The web dashboard shall refresh live sensor data at least once every 5 seconds.
2. Accuracy
• FSR sensors shall detect pressure changes with a minimum accuracy of ±5% after
calibration.
• The system shall correctly classify posture conditions (b

alanced, improper,
immobile) with at least 90% accuracy under normal usage.
• Calibration shall ensure consistent readings across all 16 FSR sensors.
3. Real-Time Monitoring Capability
• The system shall continuously monitor pressure distribution 24/7 without significant
latency or interruption.
• The Arduino Uno shall be capable of sequentially reading all 16 sensor inputs
through the multiplexer within each monitoring cycle (less than 1 second per cycle).
4. Reliability
• The system shall maintain >95% operational uptime during continuous use.
• Alerts and feedback indicators (LEDs, buzzer, OLED) shall operate consistently
under long-term use.
• The web application and database shall handle simultaneous access by multiple users
(e.g., admin, nurse, caregiver) without data loss or delay.

5. Power Efficiency
• The system shall operate efficiently on low DC voltage (5V) supplied through the
Arduino Uno board.
• Total system current draw shall not exceed 500 mA during normal operation.
• Power backup or USB operation shall ensure uninterrupted monitoring during short
power failures.

• The OLED display shall update posture status at least twice per second.
10. Network and Communication Performance
• The backend server shall process data requests and API responses within 2 seconds
for local network connections.
• Notification services (Email/WhatsApp) shall deliver alerts within 10 seconds of
detection.

intervals, and alerts are manually generated when prolonged immobility is detected.
Strengths

• Easy to implement with minimal technical resources.
• No direct patient contact with electronics; fully non-invasive.
Weaknesses:
• Highly subjective; prone to human error and inconsistency.
• Continuous monitoring is not possible; relies on caregiver presence.
• Delayed detection of improper posture or prolonged immobility.
• Cannot generate real-time alerts automatically.
4.1.2 Concept B – Wearable Physiological Sensors
Description:

pressure, accelerometer, and heart rate sensors to monitor patient posture, movement, and
physiological changes.

• Can detect subtle posture changes and im

• Possibility of integrating multiple physiological parameters for advanced
monitoring.
Weaknesses:
• Higher hardware cost per patient due to wearable devices.
• Patient compliance is required; some patients may remove or be uncomfortable with

• Complex data processing and software integration needed.
• May require wireless connectivity, increasing power consumption and maintenance

6.1 Technical Achievements and Trade-offs
The development of the smart bedsheet system resulted in successful integration of
embedded hardware, sensing technology, and software-based visualization to monitor
patient posture and immobility in real time. The system

achieved its primary objective of
detecting pressure variations using FSR sensors and providing alerts when poor posture or
prolonged immobility was detected. The ESP32 microcontroller successfully processed
sensor inputs, triggered LED and buzzer alerts, and transmitted data to the backend
interface. The system also demonstrated the capability to generate a pressure heatmap,
enabling caregivers to understand patient posture trends visually.
6.2 Limitations
While the prototype demonstrated successful functionality in detecting pressure variations
and generating real-time alerts, several limitations were identified during development and
testing. Acknowledging these constraints provides clarity on the current system boundaries
and helps define improvement paths for future iterations.
• Limi

ted Sensor Coverage:
The prototype used only five FSR sensors placed at key pressure points. Although sufficient
for proof-of-concept, this configuration may not capture fine-grained posture variations
across the entire body surface.
• Calibration Variability:
FSR sensors are sensitive to placement, fabric tension, temperature, and humidity. As a
result, calibration values fluctuated when the fabric stretched or shifted, potentially affecting
accuracy during extended usage.
• Testing Environment Constraints:
Testing was conducted primarily in controlled lab conditions using simulated loads and
short-duration trials. Real-world environments involving patient movement, perspiration,
long immobilization periods, and bedding materials were not fully evaluated.
• Power Consumption Exceeds Targe

t:
The system’s power usage was measured at approximately 5.8 W, exceeding the planned
upper limit of 5 W. Continuous sensor sampling and Wi-Fi transmission contributed to this
overhead.

43:
• Limited Clinical Validation:
The system was not tested on actual bedridden patients or medical caregivers due to ethical
and logistical constraints. As a result, user comfort, long-term reliability, and clinical
suitability could not be fully assessed.
• Basic Alert Logic:
The current prototype uses fixed threshold-based alerts. It does not yet incorporate adaptive
learning or personalization based on patient weight, movement behavior, or medical
condition.
• Single-User System:
The backend dashboard and configurations support only one patient profile at a time. Multi-
user scalability, patient differentiation, and cloud-level data management were beyond the
current scope.

expectations were referenced during design decisions.
Data Protection, Privacy, and Software Responsibility:
Although the current prototype stores data locally for testing, considerations were made for
future expansion involving cloud-based logging. To align with fundamental GDPR and
HIPAA principles, the system architecture was designed with:
• No personally identifiable information stored in the prototype phase.
• Loca

l computation of readings to avoid unnecessary transmission of sensitive data.
• Restricted access to system dashboards to prevent unauthorized use.
• Plans to apply encryption and anonymization if remote or cloud storage is
implemented in future phases.
The software logic remains transparent, explainable, and rule-based rather than using
opaque decision models. This ensures the system avoids algorithmic bias and maintains
interpretability in identifying patient risk conditions such as immobility or poor posture.
Hardware Safety and User Protection:
Since the system is intended for long-duration contact with a patient lying on a bed, strict
attention was paid to physical and electrical safety:
• Low-voltage operation (<5V logic level) to avoid electrical hazards.
• All solder joints reinfo

rced and insulated to prevent exposure.
• The electronics were positioned externally to avoid direct skin contact, aligning with
basic biocompatibility and comfort requirements.
• No sharp edges, exposed wiring, or heating elements were present, reducing risk of
burns, irritation, or injury.
